rounds.comments: (Alex: I'll give the counties, you identify the state.)

Elihu Washburne, who sponsored a bill making this man a Civil War general, became his secretary of state
Tyler appointee Abel Upshur was expelled from the College of N.J., now called this, for being in a student rebellion
Strobe Talbott is his deputy
With Lord Ashburton he negotiated the 1842 treaty that set the border for Maine
This man from Maine served James A. Garfield, Chester A. Arthur & Benjamin Harrison
William Makepeace Thackeray was an early staff member of this British humor magazine
This Canadian province's largest newspaper is the Edmonton Journal
In 1955 this monthly founded by DeWitt & Lila Wallace was forced to accept advertising for the first time
In 1954 this Civil War historian was named editor of American Heritage magazine
Perhaps best known as a sportswriter, he's been editor-in-chief of the Paris Review since 1953
Delicately-hued portraits made with these pale crayonlike sticks were popular in the 1700s
A painting applied to & made integral with a wall or ceiling, its name is from Latin for "wall"
18th C. artist Clodion sculpted nymphs & satyrs from this fired clay whose name is Italian for "baked earth"
If this paint that has one egg yolk binder is applied too thickly, it may crack
Traditionally, Pueblo Indians carve these dolls that represent spirits as teaching devices for children
Used in the Roman Catholic Church, it's a circle of 50 beads attached to a crucifix
In the 18th century, this ancient Japanese religion was revived through the writings of Mabuchi & others
In 1649 George Fox, leader of this movement, was jailed for interrupting a minister
With over 1 billion followers, it's the largest non-Christian religion
These oldest Hindu scriptures existed for centuries before they were written down
The real first name of this Peter Rabbit creator was Helen
In titles of mysteries by Lilian Jackson Braun, this animal precedes "Who Saw Red" & "Who Played Brahms"
This "Age of Innocence" author launched her career with a how-to book on "The Decoration of Houses"
This "Thorn Birds" author is an admitted Scrabbleholic; she likes to play daily
This British author dedicated her 1928 novel "Orlando" to Vita Sackville-West
An ideal knight of this "Canterbury Tales" author was valorous but "prudent and as meek as a maid of his bearing"
Patches of plate armor were added to unprotected areas of this flexible garment of interlocked metal rings
The name of this part of a knight's armor comes from an old French word meaning "glove"
A dummy target called a quintain was used in practice tilts in preparation for this sport
In about 1119 in Jerusalem, knights Hugh de Payens & Godfrey of St. Omer founded this order of Christian knighthood
This boxer liked his nickname "Marvelous Marvin" so much that he had his name legally changed
In a 27-year ring career, Archie Moore set a record by winning the most bouts, 141, in this way
3 Rays have won Olympic gold medals in boxing for the U.S.: Ray Mercer, Ray Seales & this "sweet" guy
This bare-knuckles heavyweight champ was known as "The Great John L."
1 of 2 men to whom Floyd Patterson lost the World Heavyweight title
The first new variety of Eggo waffle Kellogg's made was one with this fruit in 1972
Poutine, a Montreal treat, is covered with gravy & this solid element of cheese
This Thai food flavoring comes from a tropical plant named for its citrusy smell
Holishkes is one of the many names for leaves of this vegetable stuffed with meat
Italian for "angry", it describes a pasta sauce spiced up with plenty of chiles
Often employing animals, this type of short tale, like "The Fox and the Grapes", teaches moral lessons
Some novels have this added section about characters' later lives; the one in Ellison's "Invisible Man" is called this
This 3-letter term is inserted after a correctly quoted word or phrase that's misspelled or inaccurate
From the French for "untying", it unties the plot after the climax of a novel
This term for books printed before 1501 goes back to the Latin cunae, "a cradle"
The title of an Irving Berlin song, it's how a famous pair danced in the film "Top Hat"
A shallow or intermittent tributary
To give off a strong, unpleasant smell
Onion relative that's a symbol of Wales
It's the word that means happening once a fortnight
"It's Too Late" & "So Far Away" were 1971 hits for her
This group's "Louie Louie" made 1963 very interesting
"Stand By Me" hit the charts for him in 1961 & 1986
"The Thrill Is Gone"--at least it was for him in 1970
In 1979 this potent (potable) singer gave us "I Don't Know If It's Right"

rounds.text: In 1943 Drs. Leo Kanner & Hans Asperger each used this word for the then-unnamed disorder they were studying
